author: potuz
content: <@602753420033785856> <@425572898787426305> it was raised in prysm tracker the issue that we send unrealized justification for safe block hash instead of justified.  I was about to open a spec PR to change it to be unrealized justification when it hit me that actually we shouldn't specify this for anything. In fact I believe that we shouldn't be testing that clients send the same value here at all. There is nothing in the spec that relies on this value afaik and this is definitely something that different consumers would have divergent safety thresholds. As such I would be inclined to open a PR explicitly stating what the engine API does: some guidelines as to what this value should be, some boundaries (like being canonical) but not forcing clients to set it to anything specific. I am posting here before cause this is probably less kosher than the PR just requesting it to be unrealized justification

author: potuz
content: FWIW: we're planning on having our own implementation of safe and wanted to have a flag to expose that.

author: sproul
content: I agree that we shouldn't force all clients to do the same thing, so long as the "safe" estimates provided by each are sensible. What's Prysm's new implementation based on? The confirmation rule by Roberto et al or something else?

author: potuz
content: No set design yet, have yet to discuss with Aditya but given the crowd, most probably a variation of that. Not intended for mainnet default but rather in line with the idea that specialized users may want to have special thresholds. For example I wouldn't be surprised if some would prefer to have finalized=safe
